questions.q: What is the difference between JDK and JRE?
questions.a: JDK is for developing Java programs (includes compiler, debugger, JRE). JRE is only for running programs (JVM + libraries).
x: JDK only runs Java programs, JRE compiles them.
JDK is platform independent, JRE is platform dependent.
JDK includes JVM, but JRE does not.

questions.q: What is Java Virtual Machine (JVM)?
questions.a: An abstract machine that executes Java bytecode, making Java platform independent.
x: A compiler that converts Java code directly into machine code.
A library package included in the JDK for debugging.
A tool that translates JVM bytecode into C++.

questions.q: What are the different types of memory areas allocated by JVM?
questions.a: ClassLoader, Method Area, Heap, Stack, Program Counter, Native Method Stack.
x: Static memory, Dynamic memory, Shared memory.

questions.q: What is JIT compiler?
questions.a: Just-In-Time compiler, compiles bytecode to native code at runtime for performance.
x: A compiler used only at install time.
A tool for debugging JVM errors.
A library inside JDK for managing memory.

questions.q: How Java platform is different from other platforms?
questions.a: Java is platform-independent: code compiles to bytecode, runs on any JVM.
x: Java needs platform-specific libraries to run.
Java programs can run without JVM.
Java is platform dependent like C++.

questions.q: Why people say that Java is 'write once and run anywhere' language?
questions.a: You can write Java code on Windows and compile it in Windows platform. The class and jar files that you get from Windows platform can run as it is on Unix environment. Behind all this portability is Java byte code. Byte code generated by Java compiler can be interpreted by any JVM. So it becomes much easier to write programs in Java and expect those to run on any platform.
x: Because Java is faster than C++
Because Java runs only on Windows
Because Java compiles directly to machine code

questions.q: How does ClassLoader work in Java?
questions.a: In Java, ClassLoader is a class that is used to load files in JVM. There are three main types of ClassLoaders: Bootstrap (loads from rt.jar), Extension (loads from jre/lib/ext), and Application (depends on CLASSPATH).
x: ClassLoader is used only for networking
ClassLoader is a keyword in Java

questions.q: Do you think ‘main’ used for main method is a keyword in Java?
questions.a: No, main is just a name of method. It is not a keyword in Java. There can be multiple methods with same name main in a class file.
x: Yes, main is a reserved keyword
Yes, main is part of the JVM

questions.q: Can we write main method as public void static instead of public static void?
questions.a: No, you cannot write it like this. Any method has to first specify the modifiers and then the return value. The order of modifiers can change, so static public void main() is valid but not public void static.
x: Yes, void can go before static

questions.q: In Java, if we do not specify any value for local variables, then what will be the default value?
questions.a: Java does not initialize local variables with any default value. You must assign a value before using them.

questions.q: Let’s say, we run a Java class without passing any arguments. What will be the value of the String array of arguments in the main method?
questions.a: By default, the String array is empty, not null.

questions.q: What is the difference between byte and char data types in Java?
questions.a: byte stores binary data (-128 to 127, 8 bits); char stores characters (16 bits, 2 bytes).
x: byte and char are exactly the same
byte can store characters and char only numbers
char is 8 bits and byte is 16 bits

questions.q: What are the main principles of Object Oriented Programming?
questions.a: The main OOP principles are Abstraction, Encapsulation, Inheritance, and Polymorphism.

questions.q: What is the difference between Object Oriented Programming language and Object Based Programming language?
questions.a: OOP languages support all OOP principles (Abstraction, Encapsulation, Inheritance, Polymorphism); Object-Based languages support objects and encapsulation but not Inheritance and Polymorphism (e.g., JavaScript, VBScript).
x: Object-Based languages support Polymorphism and Inheritance

questions.q: In Java, what is the default value of an object reference defined as an instance variable?
questions.a: All instance variable object references are null by default.

questions.q: Why do we need a constructor in Java?
questions.a: Constructors create objects and set their initial state; without them, objects cannot be created.

questions.q: Why do we need a default constructor in Java classes?
questions.a: A default constructor (no-argument) is automatically provided if no other constructor exists; it ensures objects can be created when no custom constructor is defined.
x: It is optional and never used

questions.q: What is the value returned by a constructor in Java?
questions.a: A constructor returns the object it creates.

questions.q: Can we inherit a constructor in Java?
questions.a: No, Java does not allow constructors to be inherited.

questions.q: Why constructors cannot be final, static, or abstract in Java?
questions.a: Constructors cannot be final, static, or abstract because they must always have a body, cannot be overridden, and are used to initialize objects.
x: Constructors can be static or final
Constructors do not need a body
Constructors belong to the class only

questions.q: What is the purpose of the ‘this’ keyword in Java?
questions.a: ‘this’ refers to the current object instance; it differentiates instance variables from local variables, can call constructors, and refer to the current class instance.
x: It refers to static methods only
It creates a new object automatically

questions.q: Explain the concept of Inheritance?
questions.a: Inheritance allows a class to inherit common behavior and characteristics from a base class (IS-A relationship), promoting code reuse, method overriding, and polymorphism.
x: Inheritance copies all code into child class

questions.q: Which class in Java is superclass of every other class?
questions.a: Object class is the superclass of all classes in Java.

questions.q: Why does Java not support multiple inheritance?
questions.a: Multiple inheritance can cause ambiguity if parent classes have methods with the same signature; Java avoids this in implementation but allows multiple interfaces.
x: Java cannot create more than one class
Multiple inheritance is slower in Java

questions.q: In OOP, what is meant by composition?
questions.a: Composition (has-a relationship) is when a class contains an instance of another class, e.g., a Car has a SteeringWheel.
x: Composition is the same as polymorphism

questions.q: How are aggregation and composition different concepts?
questions.a: Composition is a strong 'has-a' relationship where parts are destroyed with the whole (e.g., Car and SteeringWheel); Aggregation is weaker, parts can exist independently (e.g., Library and Students).
x: Aggregation destroys all objects when parent is destroyed
Composition allows parts to exist independently

questions.q: Why are there no pointers in Java?
questions.a: Java uses object references instead of pointers, avoiding direct memory access, which simplifies memory management and garbage collection.
x: Java cannot access memory at all

questions.q: If there are no pointers in Java, then why do we get NullPointerException?
questions.a: Object references act like pointers; if a reference points to null and we access a method or field, JVM throws NullPointerException.
x: NullPointerException is caused by static methods

questions.q: What is the purpose of the ‘super’ keyword in Java?
questions.a: ‘super’ refers to the immediate parent class; it can call parent methods or constructors from a child class.

questions.q: Is it possible to use this() and super() both in the same constructor?
questions.a: No, Java requires that either this() or super() must be the first statement; both cannot be used together.
x: No, but only for abstract classes

questions.q: What is the meaning of object cloning in Java?
questions.a: Object.clone() creates an exact copy of an object with the same class and field values, similar to a copy constructor.
x: Cloning changes the class of object
Cloning copies only primitive fields, not objects
